2-2jFF1uXIAZOm609I3fSA.text: Since opening a few years ago, Yuzu has been a popular ramen spot downtown, and today, coworkers and I decided to try it. It's not a super fancy place, but everything was really nice inside- it'd be an appropriate date night restaurant. Since ramen seems to be their specialty, I gave it a go.  Vegetable ramen: 4.2/5 Dense, bold flavors penetrated my taste buds from the first sniff. I'm doing a little bit of macro counting so while I really wanted a ramen with pork belly, the fat content was too steep for me, so vegetable ramen it was... and it did not disappoint! As a meat-eater generally, the tofu was a little off-putting in color and texture but it tasted just fine! I can't really compare to other tofus, but I was satisfied with the protein. The broth had just the right amount of salt and was packed with rich foreign flavors. The noodles, I think, could have been a little more cooked through. I knocked a few points because towards the bottom of my bowl, the texture in the broth got grainy and had a strange, dominating aftertaste. I'm assuming this is because the ingredients were not integrated enough in the cooking and absorbing process.   Pro-tip: add a 30-min egg for $1. It was sweet and gooey and incredible. Do not skip out on it. I also went ahead and added kimchi and bok choy because why the h*ck not?  For $16 ($11 plus all my extras), this dish isn't an every month kind of thing, but it does taste dy-no-mite! I'd try another one, as long as it comes with the 30-min egg. Gotta get that recipe...

bXdbss0j6h4cMVeE7oLiZA.text: 3 big disclaimers to my review: 1.) Me and 3 friends went for dinner service during 4th of July 2.) I'm pretty sure there was only 1 person taking orders (and doing the bar) and 2 serving assistants. He tried to keep everything under control and didn't seem too rushed but I felt bad for how he was taking basically the whole restaurant. 3.) Asian vs. Asian Fusion are two different things to me.   Also, I just noticed their online menu is like 80% correct compared to their in-house one.  My boyfriend and my actual order: - Bacon-wrapped Shrimp (4 pcs) - Xiao Long Bao (5 pcs) - Salt and Pepper Tofu - Beef and brussel sprouts - Sichuan stir fry green beans with shrimp  - Bacon wrapped shrimp wasn't actually as bad as it looked. It didn't taste like much of anything but looked like it was overfried and a little burnt  - Xiao Long Bao -- if you really are expecting soup dumplings, go somewhere else. The dough was more like siaopao so even if there was actual soup in there, it gets absorbed so it's just like a siaopao vs. an actual Xiao long bao. Big disappointment there. - Sichuan stir fry green beans w/ shrimp not really much flavor. Definitely no spice despite it being supposedly stir fried with the Sichuan peppercorns distinct from the region. No spice, no flavor. Not worth the money, that's for sure.  - Salt and Pepper tofu was probably one of my favorite things, well made to my liking and savory.  - Beef and brussel sprouts I didn't get to taste, I left that up to my dude.   Also, looking at the menu, a lot of things are described in quotes which I thought would be pretty cool. Like a signature one liner to describe every dish but nah, everything fried had in quotes "fried golden and delicious" or something to that note. It's on like 1/3 of all their items. Was funny the first couple times I noticed it but the rest of the menu made me think if they couldn't take the time with their menu, they probably won't with the food either.   The ONLY thing saving it from 1 star is the tofu and the drinks. I forgot what the name of my drink was (it's not listed in the online menu) but it was pretty damn good although it could have been more spicy.  Edit: I probably should have known better now that I think about it, I broke my own rule and ordered Chinese food at a Japanese restaurant. Dumb mistake.

dSqru5CJGr5Cf6P0v89p5A.text: Yuzu Kitchen deserves all the hype it gets. I absolutely love the Veggie Ramen. It is so very good with the miso broth and soy-ginger infused tofu. I am not a fan of tofu, but this is so good I love it. The atmosphere is casual and fun and the service is outstanding. I have taken several out of town guests here to show off what Pittsburgh has to offer.

EubIGi60i81bKEsA3dQ7ow.text: I ordered the Wonton Ramen with a side of the scallion pancakes (not pictured) and I've definitely had much better ramen. The wontons in the ramen were fine but, the noodles were a bit too soft for my tastes and there wasnt even a lot of flavor in the broth. I also asked for the broth to be spicy, but still needed to get a side of chili oil because it just did not have enough spice to it. Additionally, the portion size of the ramen was reasonable (fair for a relatively nicer sit-down restaurant) but our appetizer had the smallest slices of scallion pancakes and only came with a total of 4, which was the part I did not think was reasonable.   I'm giving this review a 3 (rather than a 2) because the service was good and the ambience of the place was modern and filled with Cherry Blossom aesthetics but if you're looking for a good taste of ramen, I would not recommend this place unfortunately.

7WnsM-ALQ_kTv0ItoTI1OQ.text: Best ramen in Pittsburgh!   Ramen lovers I feel will get a good kick out of this place! I can't tell you how hard it is for me to find a solid restaurant that serves a  decent ramen dish, so finding this place was a real treat for myself and company. Yuzu's other selection to choose from shouldn't be overlooked as well, their appetizers were a good insight of how good the meal was going to be in my opinion.  Another thing to note is their alcohol selection, now I'm not much of a drinker but I found their selection much more vast than I was expecting. Which is great for someone picky about what to drink like myself! Other positive notes to touch on was the service I had. Overall Yuzu's Kitchen is a must in the Pittsburgh area!

R1yyhaMlGaReh0jhMZGE1w.text: Yuzu is good! This was my second time coming here. It's not the best ramen but it's honestly pretty solid. My friend and I actually ordered a lot of food, we were hungry and couldn't decide. We had ribeye Brussel sprouts, salt and pepper tofu, edamame, Bao buns and spring rolls. All of these dishes were good. The tofu was a bit too much fried for me but my friend loved it. The Brussels were very oily and the fat from the ribeye literally drenched them. But I think that was the point! I loved the edamame, cooked perfectly. The bao buns are sweet and savory. And the spring rolls were soooo crispy and good.   I ended up getting the Shoyu Tare ramen. No mushrooms but put corn instead. It's a good dish. I appreciate that their broth isn't overly salty which can truly ruin the ramen. It's good with their chili oil, too, kicks it up a bit. Good chunks of bok choy and pork belly. I especially like the egg they put in, its creamy and delicious.   My friend got chicken stir fry with sweet garlic chili. I tried it myself and it was really good. I would probably try the stir fry never time, if I'm honest.   The price is good, too. Not too expensive but not the cheapest. It's a solid place for ramen and I'd go back!

GAeYAAxAsHb10fQHTL5T5w.text: A great, convenient location near market square. And too my knowledge, the only place to get ramen downtown. KvrM4wxsk6ujYJxZkuRp6A.text: Stopped by here for dinner.  Nice looking restaurant on in the inside with plenty of seating and long bar. U1CFsKp6OaJ2Aah1qvx27A.text: Really terrible taste.  I was so angry that I signed up to write a review.  I came from Korea and missed hometown food.  It seemed good, but the noodles didn't cook properly and taste terrible. Do you see the noodles stick together?  Also, the noodles weren't much different from the noodles made at the factories that sell at Korean food markets. (2 dollars one)  I hardly understand why it is so high star.  In Korea or Japan,  I'm sure that if they provide these foods, you'll be ruined in six months.  If you say you've eaten here and have eaten ramen, it's a shame.  This is no more than just a piece of flour.  The ramen I ate in Boston was just as good as Korea or Japan, but in here, really really really x 1000 disappointed.  Moreover, how expensive is it? PnbYD2rlP8t4TFEVgehKxg.text: My husband and I love this place.  Tucked out of the way, you might miss it.  Please don't.  The service is outstanding and it has a cozy atmosphere.  This is our go to date night spot. I love the curry ramen and don't forget to add an egg and kikurage (wood ear mushroom).

FgMWMkM1HGDEdD6vd4Imuw.text: I have been here both for happy hour and for regular dinner and loved the food both times. The karaage chicken and the bao are both fantastic. The chicken is crispy and not greasy. The ramen is delicious. The karaage curry ramen and the sukiyaki beef ramen are both delicious. Served hot and the broth is flavorful and there is a good balance of noodles to the veggies and meat. The service was great - no complaints. We will definitely be going back

tVMQofjXnMYuhhWBrOo-jw.text: A group of us went to Yuzu Kitchen last night - wow.  SO impressed.  We're a bunch of ramen aficionados that are bummed about Pittsburgh's lack of good ramen - until NOW.  Yuzu has a good selection of staples - the chashu was cooked perfectly, the broths were nicely layered and deep.  We even got to taste test some of the "winter" options coming up in the next few weeks, and damn.  Needless to say, we'll be going back in the next few weeks.  Salt/pepper tofu - don't like tofu?  Are you sure?  TRY this.  Like tofu?  Ooooh you're going to be happy with these.  Gyoza - standard, delicious. Chicken on a stick - sharing?  Hoard that peanut sauce.  Don't share it with your tablemates.    Rayu ramen - nice spicy kick, perfectly cooked chashu.  I added baby bok choy and was pleased with the decision. Miso ramen - NOM.  Pulled chicken?  Delicous. General Tso's (because why not?) - CRISPY.  DEEP SMOKY/SWEET FLAVOR.  Best General Tso's I've ever had, hands down  There were other things we ate - nothing disappointed.  I'm going to try and wrap this up.  EAT HERE.  Oh, and get the kimchi - this is a daikon radish kimchi.  As someone who lived in Korea for two years - do it.  DO IT.  Crunchy, spicy, umami.  It's everything.  The ONLY bad thing that I would have to say is that the noodles aren't anything to write home about, but they weren't bad and they didn't detract from the dishes.

99dWKsxW8BhH0qDq0fyJ7w.text: I enjoyed the basil ramen with shrimp lunch, and it was so tasty and not too spicy, the service was really great.  The restaurant is clean and well managed.  I will go back for more and you should too !

hJ-7kZFnmOfEsYccCkl6SA.text: I went here when visit Pittsburgh and don't know where to eat at night, I found Yuzu on yelp, nearby where I stayed. Place is calm, price is good, and food is good. Come if you like the lounge style Japanese restaurant

FkiWtPaGRZGCopI9jDcRMQ.text: So, I and one of my intrepid lunch partners-in-crime (LPIC) decided that we were going to check out Yuzu Kitchen because we had been meaning to go there, but with the addition of so many new restaurants in Downtown Pittsburgh, it took us a minute to get there.  But get there, we did! First of all, I'm a damn dumpling fanatic.  I don't care whose cuisine we're talking about, if they have a dumpling, I'm trying it.  I asked our server about the Gyoza at Yuzu Kitchen and she said that they were her favorites.  Say no more!  Put me down for the gyoza!  GBD(Golden, Brown and Delicious!) and moist and flavorful and freshly made and tasty and porky!  Yuzu Kitchen's gyoza rank up there with some of the best that I have had in San Francisco's and New York City's Chinatown neighborhoods. (I hate when restaurants serve "frozen" gyoza and try to pawn them off as house-made.  Yech!)  As far as our entrees, me and my LPIC were going to go with the ramen but decided to go with the "Da Shoyu Mein" at the last minute. Ramen noodles with pulled pork, Korean pickled bean sprouts, scallions, mushrooms and a 30 minute egg!  What form of madness is this?  Crazy goodness!  I swore off all forms of ramen noodles after college. (When the only thing that you can afford is 10 packs for a dollar ramen noodles and you eat them almost EVERY DAY for several years, you would swear them off too!)  However, Yuzu Kitchen made me a believer and we are already contemplating eating our way through the menu. (Just to make sure that they don't have anything bad on their menu.)  And while the space is small, it is truly artfully and elegantly designed.  Tres chic!  I'm just sorry that I didn't take any pictures, but I was so hungry that I was almost completely finished with my meal before I realized that I didn't really get good photos.  Anyway, you must go and I think that you will be impressed.

zDXBxZatd74I1IldzIeUQA.text: Here is yet another example of wishing we could give half stars. I would have given them 3.5 stars. The pics show what I have had and the soup is always hot and good. The steak on the stick was also really good. Place is always packed at lunch during the week, so get there early if you can. I have been there 4 times so far and will keep going back unless something changes. I always go for the soup but I will have to try something other than that. Their prices are on point also; no crazy prices that I noticed on the menu. Note to owners: Please get garlic chips for the soup. Thank you....

RFZrVL-mSA8j1gU50stVXg.text: Went here for lunch today and ordered the veg ramen. At $12 it is a bit pricey for lunch. The ramen was rather bland/mundane. Luckily they offered some chili oil to give it some pizazz. It comes in a large bowl that is only filled about half way. I finished my meal and was still hungry. Mentally it is difficult to get over the fact that you could get over 12 portions of freeze dried top ramen for the same price! Yes, not as good, but it would be a lot cheaper and more filling. I want to say I would give this place another try, as I'm curious and interested in exploring the menu some more, but i don't think I will be throwing this place into the regular lunch rotation.

1QLikJm3WgMvh51poBHmPw.text: This is such a great place to have cocktails and enjoy delicious food. The ambiance is very nice with low lights and cool art decor. Great selection of Japanese cocktails and spirits, possibly the most varied drinks on the menu I have seen so far.

3zkGFABVyLHxJEQzXvV8Jg.text: So I should preface this review with the fact that I'm a vegan, so my options are limited. Anyway, I had the ramen noodles with their veggie broth and loaded with veggies. It was just okay. Nothing memorable about it and could have used some extra fixings to jazz it up a bit.   I will say I love the vibe in here. Although the two times I went it was literally empty on a Saturday evening, they had a nice playlist going and the bar area is super trendy. I'd be willing to come back and try their other vegan friendly apps.

ikKkMkDz22RwqQwYXxP8rw.text: From the start when I walked in, service was attentive. Which isn't necessarily good or bad? A young man in an apron approached me first to pour my water and that was a little confusing.  The menu is fairly small, and the drink selections (alcohol wise) weren't the greatest unfortunately (I forgot to ask if regular wine, beer, and liquor options existed). However, the purple drink (the name escapes me right now), was delicious when it came out.   I am the first to admit, I've been ignorant of TRUE ramen my entire life. I've only ever eaten the styrofoam bowl ramen and the microwave/hot water package ramen. To have REAL ramen for the first time was terrific, and I appreciate my server walking me through how to order it and what the differences were with patience, understanding, and appreciating the humor of it all.  To end- the ramen was amazing, the drink was delicious, and you should make your way here at the next available opportunity!

S6zQ6SMIeQ0rHPnIbQHQsg.text: Omg this was the best!!  General Tso chicken with veggies!  Delicious!  All white meat juicy chicken with perfectly fresh and tender veggies!  This place is a gem.  Service was great!!!

5ZQBNcRmf1T7q-MJF5X7ww.text: New spot in Downtown Pittsburgh on Wood Street. Please note that this review is biased because The Bar Director is my kid.  Also met The Owner. Both fellas are really nice. Had a pork ramen  with pork belly, shrooms, corn, bean sprouts and some other goodies. Have an open mind if you haven't tried ramen before and be sure to let TBD suggest your beverage. He won't steer you wrong.

Q1a-fZpZd7fZntOqvLzPiw.text: I love this place. If you're looking for good ramen and bao buns, check this place out. They have the best bao and ramen I've had in Pittsburgh. I'm originally from Philadelphia area, where my go-to place was Nom Nom Ramen in the city and this is the most similar place I've found.  Apps/small plates are cheap(even cheaper during happy hour!) but still great quality, cooked and prepared perfectly. Ramen is amazing, the shio is great; yuzu bomb is so good. Love their gyoza, bao, and spring rolls. The atmosphere is very chill. Staff has always been very friendly. Wish I could visit more often, I would seriously eat here every day if I had the funds lol

NOgNK0I-y7Z1SQKR7xE-kw.text: Excellent stir fry and shrimp fried rice! i definitely would recommend this place.

UyIGmjOztx4fteXXMQTdpQ.text: I really wanted to give Yuzu a great review because, well, I love ramen.  I tried the house Miso Ramen.  $15.  Let me level set, I pay $13 for Miso Ramen in NYC.....  Unfortunately, the Miso at Yuzu was very bland.  No spice, the broth must have been ultra low MSG.  The chicken was likely purchased from Sysco or another food distributor, baked in the oven, then shredded.  No soul, no creativity.  What a bummer.  To be fair, I had a friend who really enjoyed his spicy ramen; however, I had one meal.  That being said, I believe that everything on the menu should be prepared with the same care as the best thing on the menu, so two stars it is for the high price and low flavor.

40Fnv9lwztGhdjyIO9CCEw.text: TL;DR- bad service, bad food, unclean bathroom.  My boyfriend and I arrived at this restaurant 15-20 minutes before the rest of our party arrived, so we decided to order a couple cocktails. It wasn't especially busy in the restaurant, but it took 30 minutes to get our drinks. By the time we got our drinks the rest of the party had arrived and had been seated for enough time to look over the menu and drink menu. Another member of our party was interested in wine and ordered something off of the wine list. He was told that they had almost none of the wines on that list. As for the ramen, I tried the Yuzu shio ramen, their so called specialty. It was too spicy and you couldn't taste the ramen at all. The quality of ramen was less than I would get making frozen ramen at home. At the end of our meal I want to the bathroom, and it was disgusting. Looked like no one had been in to clean it for at least a few days. Will never come back.

6p1BUEHh8jjoALAwmQzZ3A.text: Love this place.  Great cocktails, delicious appetizers and ramen, and nice happy hour specials.  Also glad to see it's been getting busier--even though that means it's harder to just drop in!  This is a great addition to downtown's restaurant options

oM6RJNJLj3eXZlXafwpO7Q.text: I had the opportunity to check this spot out for a Wednesday lunch last week. I was surprised at how well done the design is and how upscale the materials used in the space are - I guess I just had no idea what to expect! I had a really hard time reading the menu. I feel like they could help with a definition or vocab list. Or atleast have the servers more forthcoming with explanations to help those that are uneducated. I was curious and asking questions but did not learn much about the menu's nuances :(  I ended up ordering what was described to me as an elevated ramen soup or sorts - "Shoyu Tare Paitan pork marrow / chicken broth / shoda shoyu tare / scallions sauteed mushrooms / cha-shu (marinated pork belly) 30 min egg / corn / nori".  I think I made a good choice - it was delicious! Our meal arrived within 5 mins and was very tasty and fulfilling. Great lunch spot or take out choice for those working downtown. Would like to return to try the curry options.

X4pql9aIOSNxpjEI_veBiw.text: This is the Ramen I have enjoyed most in Pittsburgh. It has a creamy broth. The ambiance of the restaurant was warm and comfortable. I plan to return.

dOQrirMvXZaWK9nxZEiNog.text: Yuzu Kitchen is filling the void in downtown.  I'm excited to have a ramen spot within walking distance and it's definitely bringing the Asian cuisine up a notch here. The restaurant is spacious and they still need to break out the comfort zone in downtown.  I like their happy hour special but they really need a ramen lunch special to compete downtown.  The ramen is not bad but at $15, I call that a bit steep.

8bW5bZsMaj3H4AYP4BFIPA.text: Ordered via UberEats. I thought the Spicy Korean stir-fry sounded pretty good. What I got did not designate at all it's description. It was more of a hunan style Chinese chicken dish. Soupy, greasy, very small portion of stewed/rubbery meat that isn't all that appetizing. The sauce was salty without any spice or flavor. Definitely loaded up on the broccoli portion which is okay if the sauce was actually tasty. I was very disappointed but I guess that's what I get for ordering something more fusion based at a seemingly more Japanese styled restaurant. But why even offer it then?

ZIecUugsC8z6y5Yh_MvsTQ.text: This was a really great experience! We called last minute for a group dinner and they were able to accommodate us. Happy hour specials are great, I loved the Kentucky mule, a fun twist on the traditional Moscow mule. Also very good prices for the quality and portion sizes of the entrees. Ambiance is also cool, I would describe it as modern and eclectic but also cozy. I would recommend this place to everyone. Pictured is one of the ramen bowls we ordered it was a garlic miso broth and super delicious.

e-C92DN231kYtY4LUZTuOA.text: So...my husband and I just walked out of here. We waited for someone to see us to at least take drink orders. Nothing. The host literally just sat people next to us and brought a carafe of water, but skipped that one with us. Then no sooner is the water at the table, the server is there to take their order! No one at all greeted us! What was that all about?? I'm vegan and I really was excited to try a new place that serves vegan food...but I guess they lost a potential customer...who, in fact had been a sever for over 10 years (ie. great tipper and not picky) thank you for not taking care of us.

M54ZBDMfnQzjAnoYYHk7ag.text: This restaurant deserves a solid 4 stars. The food is decent, and my server (Asian girl...I forgot her name but she was really nice) was excellent.  The menu is medium sized for lunch, which isn't a bad thing. I do get annoyed by those restaurants that offer a huge menu, but do everything mediocre.  Everything was good. Tasty, decent portions, and they have a bar that offers additional seating for diners.  I didn't have a chance to try the Robata grilled items on the menu. I will the next time for sure.  I like the fact that this place is more True to what an actual izakaya (Japanese pub) is supposed to be. There's an excellent place in Highland Park (Teppanyaki Kyoto), but all the other "izakaya" style restaurants in Pittsburgh are either knock offs or have completely missed the mark.  Yuzu Kitchen is a good addition to the downtown restaurant scene, and I hope they continue to do well and last for a long, long time.

jlzZa7uU1CNFhVeoLsBDEQ.text: This is probably the best ramen in town. We went late on a Saturday night, and it was emptier than I thought. The restaurant is very simple, and the waitress was great.   I had the Shoyu ramen, as well as the pork belly bao. It was quite expensive ($15/bowl of ramen), but worth it! All of the ramens, aside from the veggie ramen, were fifteen dollars a bowl. They also had dry options and rice bowl options as well.   The noodles were a bit soft (I usually like them a bit chewier), but the taste was great. I enjoyed the food, and I will be back!

Ar30JOyIZE_s4yEkoH8DMw.text: YES!  I've been eagerly awaiting the opening of this place ever since I heard about it.  Downtown Pittsburgh needs more interesting offerings to mix it up for the working crowd at lunchtime.  A friend and I came today and we both got ramen bowls and chrysanthemum iced tea, which were delicious.  I'm only holding to 4 stars because I've not yet tried the cocktails and--this is my ugly Americanness coming out--I would have liked to have seen just a *bit* more types of items on the menu.  I recognize that ramen is their star item, but perhaps we can get some dumplings and other noodle dishes up on offer?  Service was great.  Definitely making a return trip.

5Sfy60gFM0m-Uvrp86noUA.text: This place is a little hidden in the city but worth finding. Very nice interior with tables and a large bar. Reservations can be made with open table. I tried some of the happy hour specials (1/2 off select appetizers and $6 cocktails) and after that, I can't wait to go back to try their ramen. Very unique for Pittsburgh.

76IuMVooRHn0XLM8xOGMdg.text: My niece Najiyyah Floyd worked here during her time in college. She had her graduation dinner here and The food is absolutely delicious.  Everything we tried was so good. From the appetizers to the desert. The service was great as well. The Spicy Seafood Ramen was my favorite! I will be back.

UqX1p4c9Kmuj5ylPX_Z28Q.text: Yuzu Kitchen is the current go-to downtown for happy hour. The ambience, food, music and staff are great, and the cocktail menu and bar never disappoints. For my money, there is no better balance of quality mixology and price at Yuzu for happy hour. The cocktails are well-made, strong, and always changing. Overall, you will not be disappointed whether you're here for drinks or for food, or both.

NxSJn9sk9n9vg66KeyfGDg.text: First the decor is really cool. The service was great. She was very knowledgeable on what the items on the  menu are because it has a lot of un-familiar items. My husband got the Shio Paitan and he said it was the best he ever had! Very Flavorful and hearty. Me being a vegetarian was very underwhelmed and disappointed. For starters got the Bean Curd which wasnt bad but my entree of Veg  Ramon was bland, boring and hardly anything in it. I added some extra vegetable umami bomb to help which it didnt. I ended up putting spicy chili paste in it to give it some sort of flavor.  So this place is great for meat eaters but I wouldn't recommend it for Vegetarians at all. Just because I dont eat meat doesnt mean I just want bland empty bowl of tofu and noodles. I see from other reviews im not the only one who feels this way

SUg0baXUeEfPngQqbKc6Sw.text: The staff is awesome the decor is just as awesome and their happy hour menu was nice. I enjoyed I had high hopes for this place as it's now the only Ramen spot downtown. The bartender was super awesome and helpful when it came to being proactive and attentive. As I don't eat beef or pork and most of the ramen has pork marrow in it I went for the veggie Ramen and it wasn't what I thought it would be. The noodles were good, the vegetables were a nice touch but the broth was missing something. It didn't make the experience memorable. Will I go back for drinks and maybe appetizers? Yes! But the Ramen not so much. It's a nice after work spot with five dollar happy hour cocktails and half off apps.

veEcio1K9CJ1U-LjicuyPw.text: Quick service and I love the spicy curry vegetable ramen (tip: get it with the soy-sauce soaked soft boiled egg and bok choy). The amount they give is just the right amount, unlike other ramen restaurants where the portion sizes are huge.

sweQrxH-9gKGsgI40kmibw.text: Dear sweet nelly!!  The Karaage Curry Ramen is pure bliss.  They absolutely spend the time and attention to detail that makes this one of the best ramen bowls I've ever had.  The staff is awesome bartender and hostess.  Always a pleasure seeing them.  But maaaaan....  that chicken karaage will make your day with the perfect coconut curry broth with crispy fried chicken and bangin' noodles.

liXswPjQBCfU_3P-PR0nPQ.text: The food is really good. Which is what keeps me coming back. And it seems like from reading other reviews that the service is not an issue for most. Perhaps the dinner staff is more professional? As a single woman I'm used to not getting good service and this place is a prime example of not getting it right. I don't like sitting at the bar because I'm short and I'm never comfortable trying to read a book and eat at the bar. Also, bartenders typically don't make good waiters. So if you do have to ask for something like extra spicy mayo, you get the invisible eye roll. With Yuzu, there always seems to be a hassle to get a table set up for me and then I just feel awkward - like I'm really putting them out. This is the routine whether the place is full or empty. Also, I usually have to practically pounce on the waiters to get things they forgot. Everyone seems involved in bringing out food so things tend to get messed up. And everyone seems really busy but not very efficient. When your waiter walks by 3 times without making eye contact, you tend to feel ignored. In general, the wait staff during lunch seems more interested in talking about their social lives than helping their customers. This is an upscale place with a beautiful decor - it's too bad the vibe isn't matched by the staff.

43j9sXnUYugkXUvGrRy7uA.text: Best ramen in the city (as of this writing). Flavors are well balanced and meat is very tender. The dish with fried tofu was well done --- nice and crispy on the outside, and delectable and soft once in your mouth. Haven't gotten the chance to try their cocktails, but pretty much every dish we've ordered are spot on.

VM07a2D5bt3NXyJH5suxEA.text: Ramen on a cold, wintry day might be the best thing ever invented.  I've been here twice and couldn't be happier.  Both times I have gotten ramen with the 30 minute egg which I highly recommend.  The first time I got the one with the pulled chicken which was excellent.  This last time I got the one with the pork belly and mushrooms which was very spicy, but also very delicious.   A bowl runs from $12-$15 and is enough for two meals, so long as you don't eat all the "good stuff" out in one sitting - I usually do and then am left with a bowl of just noodles and broth for leftovers, but I am happy with that as well.    Excellent downtown addition with very pleasant wait staff and bartenders.  Highly recommend.
